subject: IMPORTANT: Remove YouTube and Twitter logos from footers please

comments.value:
Hi folks

We've decided we might be on dodgy ground if we continue to have the little YouTube and Twitter logos in the footer of every page.  Please can you remove the logos and just keep the words as links for now? 

I figure this might involve republishing the site, are we going to have to wait until tonight?

Hi Lars

The logos and the words both seem to be gone, we wanted to words to stay.  Can you resolve please?
Sorry Finn, i had overread this, fixed now!

Thanks Lars.

 

D'you reckon we could make them bold and underlined please?

 

________________________________
of course!

-----Original Message-----
From: Finn Concannon 
Sent: 19 February 2010 09:13
To: Deborah Elstein; Liz Goulding
Subject: Homepage promos not republishing properly

Hey you guys.

I had a look at the end of the evening last night and saw that the
homepage promos still haven't republished. They're definitely numbered
in the right order, and I republished them again last night with no joy
still. They were numbered 12, 13, 14, 40, 50, or something similar to
that, so i've them all to multiples of 10 and republished again this
morning, but that shouldn't matter should it?

Will keep an eye out to see if it works for a minute, but just wanted to
let you know so that you don't get confused if you still see Seb as the
lead promo this morning

Liz - should we be republishing Homepage B every time we alter the
banners?

comments.value: for user management stuff

Hi Liz, is this just a stub for the work we are already doing or something you and Danny have discussed separately?

The new work actually is pretty transparent to the user management screens, it kind of happens in the background via API's and all that shoudl happen is that there should be six mailing lists in Communicator that correspond to the 6 mailing lists (and a master on) that correspond to the 6 mailing lists in the CMS/UMS; the master list is an amalgamation of all lists (but this cannot be unsubbed form other than by unsubbing to all lists)

There is already a ticket about this http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/321 , but titled "Documentation: user data sharing between PostCMS and Communicator Corp" which discusses various approaches, so no harm in using this ticket as the base for the actual work (if that is what it is intended for).

We are actually very near complete on this, we're still waiting on a few things;

- exact list of fields
- clarification that only verified users are exported (we have already made a decision that this is the case so we can move on)
- permissions on Jano's account so he can send a test mail out.

thanks

Jamie

<hr width="100%">

Marna, this is because the following:
When "Expire" is clicked, the CMS rightly tries to DELETE the event (because it has never been published).
However...somewhere in the workflow triggers, a MapUpdate object is created, which "points to" the event that you're trying to delete.
So ... when the database tries to delete the Event, it says "actually, sorry, there's a MapUpdate object which points to this Event, so you're not allowed to delete it".
I'm not sure what the best way to fix this is.
I don't think that there's any way of telling, from inside the workflow, whether the item is being DELETED or EXPIRED.
That would be a help, I suppose.
However, there would still be the question of what to do in the case where DELETE is being called.
ACTUALLY! I think I've just talked myself into a solution.
 1. Get the Event workflow to check whether the event has EVER been published.
 2. If it has NEVER been published, then we (presumably, but check w. jamie) don't need to create a MapUpdate object - why would Stamen want to know about events that have never been published?
i.e.
 if (this.firstPublicationDate) {
  ...
  create MapUpdate object detailing the expiry of this event
  ...
 } else {
  // this event has never been published - so no need to create a MapUpdate.
 }
Marking this as high priority and reassigning this to Jamie for now (while Marna is away).
This is done!

subject: First round optimisation tweaks

comments.value:
Hi Liz,

This is for the first round of tweaks we have made re optimization.

- Investigation and responding to issues raised
- Resizing and reloading of sponsor images
- Resizing and reloading of manually uploaded images
- Fixing of Paralympic background images (renamed by LOCOG)
- Removal of unused styles (round 1)
- Removal of unused style sheets (an oversight on KS part / NC)
- Compression of JS libs (although most libraries we're already using the minified versions, we have left some uncompressed to aid debugging and left one of the JQuery libraries un-minified as we noticed issues on IE6 when using the minified version).
- We would like to have a separate discussion re. ideas here, ideally we'd collate and compress all the JS and CSS files on the fly but this may cause issues wit the way the page currently loads as it was not designed to work this way.
- We would also like to separately suggest some improvements to the webcam, video and sponsor logos but these will both have additional upfront work and require changes to workflow so will leave otu of this email.

This is great, Jamie. Thanks. Can you expand upon whether or not you
are investigating or actually changing things like 'Compression of JS
libraries'? I'll feed this through to ITS, and then hopefully we can
catch up properly on Wed.

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

We have minimised /libraries/ but not every last JS/CSS file will discuss why tomorrow, but in short the answer is three fold (with a solution/resolution):

1) (firstly; and *don't feed this back to ITS!*) it will save all of ~40k in other words this isn't where we should be putting the effort (it's a drip in the ocean as the rest of that page currently stands).

2) (secondly; and *also don't feed this back to ITS*) *as it stand* it will complicate the current workflow making development and testing more complex and time consuming (see point one, for the saving this just isn't worth the gain). We already minimise libraries where the biggest savings can be made.

3) *BUT* we do have a solution that solves the above, it will involve some small development work but will minimise disruption to workflow and offer lots of advantages (basically we are going to suggest that we merge and compress the CSS and JS into two respective files at delivery time with a caching mechanism)

Again *Don't feed this back to ITS* I feel like there is probably enough antagonism already and I certainly don't want to stoke the fire!! 

But our feeling is that we can do *lots of things* to improve the speed of the site (especially if starting from scratch) and are happy to do so (I imagine we can suggest lots of things ITS haven't even thought of themselves). There are also things you can ask for when commissioning new designs and internally when creating new images, which will make the biggest savings of all.

But I think is slightly unfair of ITS with no understanding of the site, workflow, our role/remit, legacy of how we we're supplied code (and the time scales we worked to once delivered that code, ie. no time to say "errm, this could be slightly more efficient") to ask us to make changes without understanding their impact.

Maybe it's not my place to say this, but I feel this could have been so better handled by initially asking to talk to us to understand why certain things are as they are and how they can be improved both now and in future. Rather than getting hung up on minimising CSS and JS files, as if we are unaware of the possibility of doing this (which TBH we fund rather patronising).

We do really clever stuff in the CMS (and other sites) with regards to reducing the footprint of CSS and JS files, but in these cases we are talking about minimising ~700k Javascript and CSS files down to a quarter of that size, which is a *real* saving (when we're trying to keep the 'total page' weight to under ~250k). We also have a different workflow in terms of how those JS and CSS files get generated. We also deliver all the icons as sprites, but once again those are never updated editorially. We also have clever cache headers and intelligent ETags in the CMS. But we have never been asked to implement these cache based performance optimisations on the 2012 site. Although in fact *we do keep an overview on things like this out of good will*. In fact only last week I fixed the Apache ETags on the live BT servers (and didn't charge you for it) which fixed an issue with the ETag's being output incorrectly making the pages largely un-cacheable (driving up your bandwidth bill and users download times).

If you'd like us to suggest more things like this in future then we're happy to so pre-emptily, maybe it is our fault in that we should have hassled you more in terms of "We think the way this JS/CSS as supplied is less than optimal" or "We could improve your cache headers" (but in truth the site didn't seem to have performance or bandwidth issues so we figured this was of a lower priority for now).

My point is we can sit down and have a really mature conversation around where we can make optimisations and whether they are better made now or as part of a new future redesign. Additionally knowing the site and CMS as we do we also can make some real world suggestions that may not have been thought about.

For a start no one at ITS has even mentioned Expired headers and an intelligent caching strategy (we have never built one as we assumed as the web host this was BT job, but more than happy to plan one out for you). This would *substantially reduce bandwidth* as all images and assets would  be cached down stream by a CDN or local ISP.

Jamie

Jamie,

 

All your work/thoughts around this are appreciated, and I agree with the
suggested approach/handling of this in future! Let's talk about it more
together (and then with ITS) tomorrow.

 

Liz

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________
